intro: Alchornea tachirensis, commonly known as the Tachira mallow, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Venezuela and Colombia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and palmate leaves. The plant produces showy yellow flowers with prominent stamens, which are typically clustered in terminal inflorescences. Alchornea tachirensis is often found in moist, shaded areas of tropical forests and is adapted to thrive in humid environments. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
